facts.text: Assessee charged with interest under sub-sec. 8 of s. 18A in assessment proceedings under Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In certain assessment proceedings under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the assessee was charged with interest under sub-see.  8  of P. 18A of that Act,

facts.text: Assessee contends that the company could not be made liable to pay the interest as it could not be calculated in the manner indicated in sub-sec. 6 of s. 18A.

facts.text: There are three appeals because there are three orders charging interest under s.18A(8), one for each of three assessment years.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the present appeals by him. There are three appeals because there are three orders charging interest under s-18A 8 , one in respect of each of three assessment years.

facts.text: Assessee's contention rejected by the Appellate Commissioner.

facts.text: Respondent Commissioner obtained a reference to the High Court of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Commissioner thereupon obtained a reference of the following question to the High Court of Punjab for its decision

facts.text: High Court answered the question against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered that question against the assessee. Hence the present appeals by him.

facts.text: Sub-section 3 of s.18A applies to the assessee as he had not been assessed before.

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section applies to the assessee in the present case for he had number been assessed earlier.

facts.text: Assessee neither submitted any estimate nor paid any tax under s.18A(3).

anchor.surface_text: The assessee however neither submitted any estimate number paid any tax.

facts.text: Assessee admits sub-sec. 3 of s.18A applies to him and he should have made estimate and paid tax but did not.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee does number dispute that sub-secs  3 of s. 18A applies to him and that he should have made an estimate and paid tax according to it but he has number done either.

facts.text: Assessee admits he is a person to whom sub-sec. 8 applies.

anchor.surface_text: He admits that he is a person to whom sub-sec.  8 applies.

facts.text: Assessee contends interest cannot be calculated in manner of sub-sec.6 since no tax paid.

anchor.surface_text: His companytention is that in his case since he has number paid tax at all, it is number possible to calculate interest in the manner laid down in sub-sec. 6 .

facts.text: No other objection by assessee to orders under sub-sec.8.

anchor.surface_text: To clear the ground we may state before proceeding further that the assessee has numberother objection to the orders under sub-sec.  8  making him liable for interest.

facts.text: Payment of advance tax to be made on June 15, September 15, December 15, and March 15.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that these appeals are dismissed and the decision of the High Court answering the question framed is upheld for the reasons earlier mentioned.

issues.text: The only question that arises in this appeal is whether this contention is right

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises in this appeal is whether this contention is right.

issues.text: Whether, on a true construction of sub-Sections 6, 8 and 9 of Section 18A of the Indian Income-tax Act, the interest referred to in sub-Section 8 is chargeable for failure on the part of an assessee to submit an estimate of his income and pay tax, as required by the terms of sub-Section 3 of that Section.

arguments.claim: Sub-sec.8 clearly imposes liability to pay interest, calculated in manner laid down in sub-sec.6

anchor.surface_text: That sub-section  8  intended to and did in the clearest term impose a charge for interest seems to us to be beyond dispute. It says that interest calculated in a certain mariner shall be added to the tax.

arguments.claim: Provision in sub-sec.8 lays down machinery for assessing amount of interest; construe to make machinery workable (ut res valeat potius quam pereat)

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well recognised that the rule of companystruction on which the assessee relies applies only to a taxing provision and has numberapplication to all provisions in a taxing statue. It does number, for example, apply to a provision number creating a charge for the tax but laying down the machinery for its calculation

arguments.claim: Machinery sections construed to effectuate charging sections; statute designed to be workable

anchor.surface_text: The provisions in a taxing statute dealing with machinery for assessment have to be companystrued by the ordinary rules of companystruction, that is to say, in accordance with the clear intention of the legislature which is to make a charge levied effective.

anchor.surface_text: Now there are three stages in the imposition of a tax there is the declaration of liability, that is the part of the statute which determines what persons in respect of what property are liable. Next, there is the assessment, Liability does number depend on assessment.

holdings.text: The rule of construction applicable to taxing statutes (strict/literal construction) applies only to taxing or charging provisions and has no application to machinery provisions for calculation or collection of tax.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well recognised that the rule of construction on which the assessee relies applies only to a taxing provision and has no application to all provisions in a taxing statue. It does not, for

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well recognised distinction; cites Mahaliram Ramjidas (PC), India United Mills (SC), Whitney v CIR; machinery construed by ordinary rules to effectuate charge.

holdings.text: Section 18A(8) clearly and in the plainest terms imposes a liability to pay interest, calculated in the manner laid down in Section 18A(6), to be added to the assessed tax.

anchor.surface_text: That sub-section 8 intended to and did in the clearest term impose a charge for interest seems to us to be beyond dispute. It says that interest calculated in a certain mariner shall

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.18A(8) creates charge; no need for equity or alteration; distinguishes from calculation machinery.

holdings.text: Machinery provisions like the calculation method in s.18A(6) for interest under s.18A(8) must be construed to make them workable (ut res valeat potius quam pereat), rather than defeating the liability.

anchor.surface_text: The proper way to deal with such a provision is to give it an interpretation which, to use the words of the Privy Council in Mahairam Kamjidass 1 case ,makes the machinery workable,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies ordinary construction to assessment machinery to secure workability and effectuate legislative intent; cites PC in Mahaliram.

holdings.text: In cases of no advance tax payment under s.18A(8), interest under s.18A(6) is calculated from the 1st day of January in the financial year in which the tax ought to have been paid.

anchor.surface_text: If however the portion of sub-see. 6 which we have quoted above is read as, from the 1st day of January in the financial year in which the tax ought to have been paid, the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adapts wording of s.18A(6) without violence to make workable for non-payment cases; aligns payers of less with non-payers; fair and intended.

holdings.text: Where no advance tax is paid, the shortfall for interest calculation under s.18A(6) is the entire eighty per cent of the tax determined on regular assessment.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the other question about there being no shortfall between eighty per cent. of the amount of tax found payable on the regular assessment and the amount of tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical application: no payment means shortfall equals full 80% required; simple and natural reading.

holdings.text: The provision in s.18A(9) for penalty does not affect the construction of s.18A(6) and (8) or assist in resolving the issue; penalty is additional and for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see that this provision in any way affects the construction of sub secs. 6 or 8 or assists in the solution of the, difficulty which has arisen in

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18A(9) addresses untrue estimates or non-compliance differently from interest liability; harmonious construction keeps them distinct.

holdings.text: Interest under s.18A(8) is chargeable for failure to submit estimate and pay advance tax under s.18A(3), calculated per adapted s.18A(6).

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that these appeals are dismissed and the decision of the High Court answering the question framed is upheld for the reasons earlier mentioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court on reference question by applying above constructions; rejects assessee's contention.

precedents.citation: Cape Brandy Syndicate v.Inland Revenue Commission,  1

anchor.surface_text: Cape Brandy Syndicate v.Inland Revenue Commission,  1 . In a taxing Act one has to look merely at what is clearly said. There is numberroom for any intendment. There is numberequity about a tax. There is numberpresumption as to a tax. Nothing is to be read in, numberhing is to be implied.

precedents.case_name: Cape Brandy Syndicate v Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: In a taxing Act one has to look merely at what is clearly said. There is no room for any intendment. There is no equity about a tax. There is no presumption as to a tax. Nothing is to be read in, nothing is to be implied. One can only look fairly at the language used.

anchor.surface_text: In re Bethlem Hospital  2 . This Court has accepted this rule.  1   1921  1 K.B. 64, 71.  2   1875  L.R. 19 Eq. 475, 459. Bhagwati J. in A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala  1  said, If the case is number companyered within the four companyners of the provisions of the tax-

precedents.cited_proposition: The object of this rule is to prevent a taxing statute being construed according to its intent, though not according to its words.

precedents.citation: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala  1

anchor.surface_text: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala  1  said, If the case is number companyered within the four companyners of the provisions of the tax- ing statute, numbertax can be imposed by inference or by analogy or by trying to probe into the intentions of the legislature and by companysidering what was the substance of the matter.

precedents.case_name: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: If the case is not covered within the four corners of the provisions of the taxing statute, no tax can be imposed by inference or by analogy or by trying to probe into the intentions of the legislature and by considering what was the substance of the matter.

precedents.citation: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Baldnoch Distillery Co. Ltd.  2

anchor.surface_text: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Baldnoch Distillery Co. Ltd.  2  The assessee therefore companytends that on the plain words of sub-as.  8  and  6  he cannot be charged any interest and in fact in a case like his, subsection  8  has to be regarded as of numbereffect.

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Baldnoch Distillery Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: If the provision is so wanting in clarity that no meaning is reasonably clear, the courts will be unable to regard it as of any effect.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mahaliram Ramjidas  3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mahaliram Ramjidas  3  it was said, The Section, although it is part of a taxing Act, imposes numbercharge on the subject, and deals merely with the machinery of assessment. In interpreting provisions of this kind the rule is that companystruction should be preferred which make the machinery workable utres valeat potius quam pereat.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mahaliram Ramjidas
precedents.cited_proposition: The Section, although it is part of a taxing Act, imposes no charge on the subject, and deals merely with the machinery of assessment. In interpreting provisions of this kind the rule is that construction should be preferred which makes the machinery workable utres valeat potius quam pereat.

precedents.citation: India United Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax  1

anchor.surface_text: India United Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax  1  This Court observed, That section is, it should be emphasised, number a charging section, but a machinery section. And a machinery section should be so companystrued as to effectuate the charging sections.

precedents.case_name: India United Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: That section is not a charging section, but a machinery section. And a machinery section should be so construed as to effectuate the charging sections.

precedents.citation: Whitney v. Commissioners 2 of Inland Revenue

anchor.surface_text: Whitney v. Commissioners 2 of Inland Revenue My Lords, I shall number permit myself a general observation. Once that it is fixed that there is liability, it is antecedently highly improbable that the statute should number go on to make that liability effective.

precedents.case_name: Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Once that it is fixed that there is liability, it is antecedently highly improbable that the statute should not go on to make that liability effective. A statute is designed to be workable and the interpretation thereof by a Court should be to secure that object.

anchor.surface_text: Allen v. Trehearne where s. 45 5  of the English Finance Act, 1927 which laid down that Where in any year of assessment a person ceases to hold an office or employment chargeable under Schedule E tax shall be charged for that year on the amount of his emoluments for the period beginning on the sixth day of April in that year and ending on the date of the cessation came up for companystruction.

precedents.cited_proposition: The rules in Section 45, Sub-section 5 and 6, are rules affecting assessment and collection, and that if there is any difficulty in the precise applicability of the language of those Sub-sections, it should be interpreted largely and generously in order not to defeat the main object of liability laid down by Rule 1 of Schedule E.
precedents.cited_holding: It is legitimate to treat the words 'his emoluments' as meaning on the amount of the emoluments attaching to the office which he held.

anchor.surface_text: Mahairam Kamjidass 1 case ,makes the machinery workable, utres valeat potius quam pereat. We, therefore, think that we should read sub-sec.  6 , according to the provision of which interest has to be calculated as provided in sub-sec.  8  in a manner which makes it workable and thereby prevent the clear intention of sub-sec.  8  being defeated.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mahaliram Ramjidas
precedents.cited_proposition: makes the machinery workable, utres valeat potius quam pereat
